overview: The legislature finds that patrons leaving a liquor establishment can adversely affect neighboring residents and users of nearby public facilities. [1] The legislature further finds that section 281-39.5, Hawaii Revised Statutes, currently applies only to the issuance of new liquor licenses, but not the renewal of current licenses, thus creating a safe harbor for existing establishments. [1] Accordingly, the purpose of this Act is to provide communities the opportunity to protest the renewal of certain liquor licenses. [1]
appropriations: The provided legislative documents for H.B. NO. 2 do not contain any appropriations. [1]
assumptions_and_methodology: The provided documents do not contain any assumptions or methodology related to fiscal impact. [1]
agency_impact: The Liquor Commission or other licensing agency of each county shall deny the renewal of certain current liquor licenses upon receipt of sufficient protests. [1] This section shall apply to both the issuance of new liquor licenses, and the renewal of existing liquor licenses, for on-site sale and consumption by the drink. [1] This Act does not affect rights and duties that matured, penalties that were incurred, and proceedings that were begun before its effective date. [1]
economic_impact: The provided text does not specify any direct economic impacts resulting from this measure. [1]
policy_impact: This Act amends Section 281-39.5, Hawaii Revised Statutes, to apply to both the issuance of new liquor licenses and the renewal of existing liquor licenses. [1] This removes what the legislature finds to be a safe harbor for existing establishments seeking a renewal of their liquor license. [1] The purpose of this Act is to provide communities the opportunity to protest the renewal of certain liquor licenses. [1]
